replyTo.text: @vivnat I agree - evaluation on knowledge is only one part of medical expertise whether human or machine. I commend your group's inclusion of eval on adversarial questions, and I believe that robustness to rare but consequential failure cases has an outsized importance in medicine!

@HarshaNori However, this is misleading and key gaps and limitations around factuality, safety and bias are only revealed under rigorous (human) evaluation. 

Hence the need for finetuning / specialization/ alignment to the requirements of the medical domain.

replyTo.text: @HarshaNori We have repeatedly stressed in our papers and any long form interviews (which allows nuance) that general purpose LLMs like PaLM and GPT have strong medical knowledge encoded in them and thus exhibit strong performance on knowledge benchmarks such as MedQA (USMLE).

activity.text:
In many talks about our "pre-train large model on large web data" line of work, I've been asked "but this only works on ImageNet right? It will fail on, say, medical data!"
Nope. This paper (and a few others before) gets great results just fine-tuning our older BiT model.

1/2 https://t.co/ddbwoD4Xg5

quoted.text:
Robust and Efficient Medical Imaging with Self-Supervision

Presents REMEDIS, which achieves strong data-efficient generalization, matching strong supervised baselines using between 1% to 33% of data across tasks via supervised transfer learning + SSL.

activity.text: @giffmana ULMFit showed the effectiveness of pre-fine-tuning for NLP. So, for me, it was natural to try the same idea on vision datasets (non-natural ones in specific). My preliminary results were quite good in fact.

activity.text:
Interesting work but don't buy the need for model saliency maps to match expert radiologist annotations. 

If models are to exceed clinician performance, they will likely need to use different (and ideally complementary) features compared to humans.

quoted.text: A @StanfordAIMI team takes on saliency maps: “We show that saliency maps are consistently worse than expert radiologists at localizing a variety of pathologies on chest X-rays, suggesting that deep learning explainability is far from ready for use in the clinical setting.”

activity.text: What we actually need are good tests/methods to determine with high fidelity whether the features used by the model are new biomarkers or spurious correlations.
